title: 105_s896
content: The Landmine Elimination Act of 1997 may be cited as the official title. Key findings are outlined in the Act. Congress found that a moratorium on anti-personnel landmines was supported by senior military officers and would not compromise military effectiveness. They noted the significant casualties caused by landmines in Vietnam and Bosnia. The text chunk discusses the casualties caused by landmines, including injuries and deaths among soldiers under NATO command. It also mentions international efforts to ban anti-personnel landmines, such as declarations by President Clinton, the Organization of American States, and the Organization of African Unity. Additionally, it highlights Canada's announcement to pursue negotiations on a treaty banning landmines and the United Nations General Assembly's vote in favor of a ban. The United Nations General Assembly passed a resolution to pursue a treaty banning anti-personnel landmines, with formal negotiations scheduled to begin in Oslo, Norway in September 1997. The United States could secure broad support for the treaty, which would enhance security and humanitarian interests by deterring the use of landmines against its Armed Forces and civilians. The treaty aims to enhance security and humanitarian interests by deterring the use of landmines against Armed Forces and civilians. SEC. 3. RESTRICTION ON NEW DEPLOYMENTS OF ANTI-PERSONNEL LANDMINES. Beginning on January 1, 2000, no funds may be used for new deployments of anti-personnel landmines. The Secretary of Defense must submit a report to Congress within 180 days outlining alternatives for landmine deployments on the Korean Peninsula. The President can delay the restriction if new deployments are deemed essential for the defense of South Korea during a war or emergency. The President declared an emergency in Korea for the defense of the Republic of Korea. The report must include efforts to implement proposals for landmine deployments on the Korean Peninsula. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "anti-personnel landmine" refers to munitions designed to detonate by a person's presence, proximity, or contact, causing harm. "New deployments of anti-personnel landmines" are those placed after January 1, 2000, excluding command-detonated Claymore munitions.
